description: From Latin sulcātus, perfect passive participle of sulcō (“I plough, furrow”).

adjectives.description: sulcate (comparative more sulcate, superlative most sulcate)

entries.meaning: Having deep, narrow sulci, grooves or furrows.
examples: The infant's ossature, the thin and brindled bones along whose sulcate facets clove old shreds of flesh and cerements of tattered swaddle.
